sections.doco:title: Univalence of mappings from half-plane to a polygonal domains with infinite sets of vertices.
sections.doco:abstract: We apply solutions of the Hilbert boundary value problem with discontinuous coefficients and two-side curling at the infinity of logarithmic order to the construction of the formula of conformal mapping for a half-plane onto a polygonal domain with a countable set of vertices. We prove a sufficient condition of univalence of such mappings.
sections.doco:list_of_authors: E. N. Karabasheva, P. L. Shabalin
sections.doco:subtitle: Univalence of mapping
sections.doco:keywords:
Riemann--Hilbert boundary value problem, Schwarz--Christoffel integral, curling
at infinity, univalent function
doco:chapter:
A well known Schwarz--Christoffel formula gives conformal mappings of the upper half-plane onto a given polygon (see, e.g., \cite{LSh}). The formula of conformal mapping includes unknown preimages of vertices as parameters. These parameters are called accessary and they are to be defined. The development of analytical and numerical methods
of finding conformal mappings required the development of a various methods
 to find these parameters, and the extensions of the  Schwarz--Christoffel integral in case of countable set of vertices for a given polygonal area with the following boundary properties: symmetry of translation, self-similarity and others. (see, e.g.,[2-4]).

In this paper we study the generalization of	M. A.	Lavrentjev \cite{LSh} inverse problem about construction of the conformal mapping
of the upper half-plane with known preimages of vertexes onto polygon with given angles at unknown vertices in case of countable set of angles and infinite rotation of tangent going along domain boundary. No other geometric characteristics of the polygonal area are assumed.
We develop the formula of the mapping function which generalizes a well-known Schwarz--Christoffel integral for this case and prove the existence of the univalent mappings from constructed ones.

Let $D_z$ be a simply connected region in complex plane, $L_z=\partial D_z$ consist of two 	 polygonal lines $L_z^1$ and $L_z^2$ with a common point $A_0(0,0)$, each of lines has the infinite number of the rectilinear elements. Let's denote
vertices of $L_z^1$ as $A_1,A_2,\cdots$, and vertices of
$L_z^2$ as $A_{-1},A_{-2},\cdots$. They are sequentially numbered from point $A_0$. Moving from the point $A_0$ along $L_z^1$ domain
$D_z$ is on the left, and moving along $L_z^2$ it is on the right. We assume that angles $\eta_0^1\pi$, $\eta_0^2\pi$ are certain and formed by real axis with parts of broken lines $L_z^1$, $L_z^2$ starting at $A_0$  respectively, $0\leq\eta_0^1\pi<2\pi$,
$0<\eta_0^2\pi- \eta_0^1\pi<\pi/2$, and $\alpha_k\pi$ are angles at vertex $A_k$ and these are interior angles for domain $D_z$, $0<\alpha_k<1$, and $\alpha_{-k}\pi$ are angles at vertex $A_{-k}$, $1<\alpha_{-k}<2$, $k=\overline{1,\infty}$. Interior angle at vertex $A_0$ equals $(\eta_0^2-\eta_0^1)\pi$.



Let $z(\zeta)$ map upper half-plane $D$
in the complex plane $\zeta=\xi+i\eta$ onto domain
$D_z$ so that real axis $\xi>0$ corresponds to line $L_z^1$ , the origin corresponds to point $A_0$,
the end of line $L_z^1$ corresponds to point $\zeta=+\infty$. And $L_z^2$ corresponds to real axis $\xi<0$. Let's denote the points of real axis $\Im\zeta=0$ as $t_k$, $t_{-k}$ , they correspond to the vertices $A_k$, $A_{-k}$ of line $L_z$, and $0<t_k<t_{k+1}$, $t_{-k-1}<t_{-k}<0$,
$k=\overline{1,\infty}$, $\lim_{k\to\infty}t_k=+ \infty$,
$\lim_{k\to\infty}t_{-k}=-\infty$.
Let's introduce the sequence of numbers
$
\kappa_k=1-\alpha_k, ~0<\kappa_k<1, \quad \kappa_{-k}=\alpha_{-k}-1,
~ 0<\kappa_{-k}<1, \quad k=\overline{1, \infty}.
$
The problem of mapping the half-plane on the polygon with
infinite number of vertices has been considered in \cite{SSh1}, when the series
\begin{equation}\label{SK1}
\sum\limits_{j=1}^\infty\kappa_j,\quad
\sum\limits_{j=1}^\infty\kappa_{-j},
\end{equation}
converge, and the sum of these series (denoted by $\kappa^+,$$\kappa^-,$ respectively) obey $\kappa^++\kappa^-<3.$ The latter inequality in the situation considered in  \cite{SSh1}, where the tangent to the $L_z^1$, moving  round the contour from point $A_0$ in the positive direction, rotates counter anticlockwise, and the tangent to the $L_z^2$ rotates clockwise, is a necessary and sufficient condition for the univalence.





Construction of a function of a conformal mapping  when series (\ref{SK1}) diverge is
performed in work \cite{SSh6} using solution of uniform Hilbert boundary value problem with countable set of points of discontinuity of coefficients of boundary condition and two-side curling at infinity with power type.

In this article we consider the problem of constructing a conformal mapping  of the half-plane onto polygonal region when series (\ref{SK1}) diverge,
that leads to logarithmic curling of Gilbert boundary condition.

We introduce, like in \cite{SSh6}, a piecewise constant function
$$
n_-^*(\xi)=\left\lbrace\begin{array}{ll} \displaystyle{0,\quad
0<\xi<-t_{-1},}\\[3mm] \displaystyle{\sum\limits_{j=1}^k\kappa_{-j},~
-t_{-k}<\xi<-t_{-k-1}},
\end{array}\right.\quad n_+^*(\xi)=\left\lbrace\begin{array}{ll} \displaystyle{0,\quad
0<\xi<t_1,}\\[3mm] \displaystyle{\sum\limits_{j=1}^k\kappa_{j},~
t_k<\xi<t_{k+1}}.
\end{array}\right.
$$
Let's require the sequence of points $t_k$, $t_{-k}$ and numbers $\kappa_k$,
$\kappa_{-k}$ to satisfy
\begin{equation}\label{SK2}
\lim\limits_{\xi\to+\infty}\frac{n^*_+(\xi)}{\ln^{\kappa_+}\xi}=\Delta_+,\quad
\lim\limits_{\xi\to+\infty}\frac{n^*_-(\xi)}{\ln^{\kappa_-}\xi}=\Delta_-,
\end{equation}
with some constants $\Delta_+>0,$$\Delta_->0,$$1\leq\kappa_+\leq3,$$1\leq\kappa_-\leq3.$
On the assumption
\begin{equation}\label{SK3}
\sum\limits_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{t_k}<\infty,\quad
\sum\limits_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{|t_{-k}|}<\infty,
\end{equation}
we define  analytical in the upper half-plane functions like in \cite{SSh6}$
P_{+}(\zeta)=\prod\limits_{k=1}^{\infty}\left(1-\zeta/t_{k}\right)
^{\kappa_{k}},\quad
P_{-}(\zeta)=\prod\limits_{k=1}^{\infty}\left(1-{\zeta}/{t_{-k}}\right)
^{\kappa_{-k}},
$
where
$
\left(1-{\zeta}/{t_{j}}\right)^{\kappa_{j}}=|
1-{\zeta}/{t_{j}}|
^{\kappa_{j}}e^{i\kappa_{j}\arg(1-\zeta/t_{j})},\quad j=\pm 1,\pm 2,
\cdots,
$
and $\arg(1-\zeta/t_{j})$ is a singlevalued branch, which
vanishes in $\zeta=0$ and continuous in plane $\zeta$,
which is cut along the real axis, connecting points $t=t_{j}$,
$t=+\infty$ when $j>0$, and connecting points $t=-\infty$, $t=t_{j}$ when $j<0$.

For points of segments of broken lines $A_kA_{k+1}$, $A_{-k-1}A_{-k}$ we have
\begin{equation}\label{SK4}
z'(\xi)=|z'(\xi)|e^{i\nu(\xi)},\quad \xi\in(t_k,t_{k+1}),~
\xi\in(t_{-k-1},t_{-k}),~k=\overline{1,\infty}.
\end{equation}
Due to restrictions  on $D_z$ for  the argument of boundary values of a derivative of the function that conformly maps from $D$ to $D_z$, we obtain
\begin{equation}\label{SK5}
\nu(\xi)= \left\lbrace\begin{array}{lll}
\displaystyle{\pi(\eta_0^2-1+n^*_-(-\xi)),\quad
\xi\in(-\infty,0),}\\[1mm]
\displaystyle{\pi(\eta_0^1+n_+^*(\xi)
),\quad \xi\in(0,+\infty).}\\
\end{array}\right.
\end{equation}
From (\ref{SK4}) we obtain the following system of conditions
\begin{equation}\label{SK6}
\displaystyle{\Im\Bigl[e^{-i\nu(\xi)}z'(\xi)\Bigr]=0,}\\[3mm] \quad
\displaystyle{\Re\Bigl[e^{-i\nu(\xi)}z'(\xi)\Bigr]>0.}
\end{equation}
The first equation from (\ref{SK6}) is a boundary condition of the homogeneous Hilbert boundary value problem
with  countable set of points of discontinuity of the first-order at points $t_k,$$t_{-k}$.
From (\ref{SK5}), (\ref{SK2}) we have
$\nu(\xi)=O(\ln^{\kappa_+}\xi),~\xi\to+\infty$ and $\nu(\xi)=O(\ln^{\kappa_-}|\xi|),~
\xi\to-\infty$, this is the problem with two side curling at infinity of logarithmic type. The general solution of similar problem was found in work \cite{SSh7}. We need a particular solution of this problem. Taking into account
$$
\arg P_-(\xi)= \left\lbrace\begin{array}{ll} \displaystyle{0,\qquad
\xi>t_{-1},}\\[3mm]
\displaystyle{\sum\limits_{j=1}^k\kappa_{-j}\pi, \;
\xi\in(t_{-k-1},t_{-k}),}
\end{array}\right.\quad
\arg P_+(\xi)= \left\lbrace\begin{array}{ll} \displaystyle{0,\qquad
\xi<t_{1},}\\[3mm]
\displaystyle{-\sum\limits_{j=1}^k\kappa_{j}\pi, \;
\xi\in(t_{k},t_{k+1}),}
\end{array}\right.
$$$k=\overline{1,\infty},$ and equation (\ref{SK5}), we rewrite (\ref{SK6}) in the form
\begin{equation}\label{SK7}
\Im\left[e^{-i\eta_0^1\pi}z'(\xi)\frac{P_+(\xi)}{P_-(\xi)}\xi^{1-(\eta_0^2-\eta_0^1)}\right]=0,
\quad
\Re\left[e^{-i\eta_0^1\pi}z'(\xi)\frac{P_+(\xi)}{P_-(\xi)}\xi^{1-(\eta_0^2-\eta_0^1)}\right]>0.
\end{equation}
Formula (\ref{SK7}) implies that function
$
F(\zeta)=e^{-i\eta_0^1\pi}\zeta^{1-(\eta_0^2-\eta_0^1)}z'(\zeta){P_+(\zeta)}/{P_-(\zeta)}
$
may be continued symmetrically onto the lower half-plane, i.e.
$F(\zeta)$ is an arbitrary entire function satisfying the condition of mirror symmetry.
From the latter equation we obtain
\begin{equation}\label{SK9}
z'(\zeta)=\frac{e^{i\eta_0^1\pi}P_-(\zeta)}{\zeta^{1-(\eta_0^2-\eta_0^1)}P_+(\zeta)}F(\zeta).
\end{equation}
As we are interested in univalence mappings of the upper half plane by $z(\zeta)$(it's necessary to meet condition $z'(\zeta)\not=0$), and we are satisfied with solution (\ref{SK9})
where entire function  $F(\zeta)$ is a constant $a_0,$ and due to condition  (\ref{SK7}) it is positive, i.e. $F(\zeta)=a_0,$$a_0>0.$ Integrating (\ref{SK9}) along a curve that entirely lies in the upper half plane, we obtain the solution of the problem of construction of required mapping
\begin{equation}\label{SK10}
z(\zeta)=a_0\int\limits_0^\zeta\frac{e^{i\eta_0^1\pi}}{\zeta^{1-
(\eta_0^2-\eta_0^1)}}\frac{\prod_{k=1}^\infty\left(1-\frac{\zeta}{t_{
-k}}\right)^{\kappa_{-k}}}{\prod_{k=1}^\infty\left(1-\frac{\zeta}{
t_{k}}\right)^{\kappa_k}}d\zeta,
\end{equation}\begin{theorem}\label{SK1}
If function $z(\zeta)$ establishes conformal mapping of the upper half plane onto the  interior of the polygonal area with angles $\alpha_k\pi$, $\alpha_{-k}\pi$,
$k=\overline{1,\infty},$ at the vertices $A_k$, $A_{-k}$, and given sequences of numbers $\kappa_k=1-\alpha_k,$ $\kappa_{-k}=\alpha_{-k}-1$ and points $t_k,$ $t_{-k}$ are two monotone sequences on the real axis, which correspond to the vertices of this polygon, satisfy conditions (\ref{SK2}), (\ref{SK3}), then $z(\zeta)$ is represented by formula (\ref{SK10}), where
$a_0$  is an arbitrary positive constant, $\eta_0^1\pi$, $\eta_0^2\pi$ are angles,
formed by the real axis with parts of broken lines starting at $A_0$ ($0\leq\eta_0^1\pi<2\pi$,
$0<\eta_0^2\pi- \eta_0^1\pi<\pi/2$).
\end{theorem}
We consider the issue of existence and equality of one-side limits $\lim\limits_{\xi\to+\infty}z(\xi)$ and $\lim\limits_{\xi\to-\infty}z(\xi)$
of boundary values of mapping (\ref{SK10}). Like in \cite{SSh6} we estimate the right-hand side of the equality
\begin{equation}\label{SK11}
z(-r)-z(r)=r\int\limits_0^\pi z'(re^{i\theta})ie^{i\theta}d\theta.
\end{equation}
For functions $\ln P_+(\zeta),$$\ln P_-(\zeta)$
the formulas
$$
\ln P_+(\zeta)=-\zeta\int\limits_{0}^{+\infty}\frac{n_+^*(\tau)}{\tau(\tau-\zeta)}d\tau,\quad
\ln P_-(\zeta)=\zeta\int\limits_{0}^{+\infty}\frac{n^{*}_-(\tau)}{\tau(\tau+\zeta)}d\tau,
$$
were proved in \cite{SSh3}. We rewrite them as
\begin{equation}\label{SK12}
\ln
P_+(\zeta)=-\zeta\Delta_+\int\limits_{t_1}^{+\infty}\frac{\ln^{\kappa_+}\tau d\tau}{\tau(\tau-\zeta)}
+I_{+}(\zeta), \quad I_{+}(\zeta)=
-\zeta\int\limits_{t_1}^{+\infty}\frac{n^{*}_{+}(\tau)-
\Delta_+\ln^{\kappa_+}\tau}{\tau(\tau-\zeta)}d\tau.
\end{equation}\begin{equation}\label{SK13}
\ln
P_{-}(\zeta)=\zeta\Delta_-\int\limits_{-t_{-1}}^{+\infty}\frac{\ln^{\kappa_-}\tau
d\tau}{\tau(\tau+\zeta)}+I_{-}(\zeta),\quad I_-(\zeta)=
\zeta\int\limits_{-t_{-1}}^{+\infty}\frac{n^{*}_{-}(\tau)-
\Delta_-\ln^{\kappa_-}\tau d\tau}{\tau(\tau+\zeta)}.
\end{equation}
When $r\to +\infty$, asymptotical estimations follow from condition (\ref{SK2}), see \cite{SSh7}$$
I_+(re^{i\theta})=o(\ln^{\kappa_++1}\zeta),~\delta\leq\theta\leq2\pi-\delta,\quad I_-(re^{i\theta})=
o(\ln^{\kappa_-+1}\zeta),~-\pi+\delta\leq\theta\leq\pi-\delta.
$$
Further, we need more information about functions $I_+(\zeta),~ I_-(\zeta),$ to obtain it we introduce new restrictions on sequence of points of discontinuity.
Let's denote
$
n_+^*(t_k)-\Delta_+\ln^{\kappa_+}t_k=p_k,\quad n_+^*(t_k)-\Delta_+\ln^{\kappa_+}t_{k+1}=
q_k,
$$
n_-^*(t_{-k})-\Delta_-\ln^{\kappa_-}-t_{-k}=p_{-k},\quad n_-^*(t_{-k})-\Delta_-\ln^{\kappa_-}-t_{-k-1}=q_{-k},
$
we assume, that numbers $p_k,$$p_{-k}$, $q_k,$$q_{-k}$ satisfy conditions
\begin{equation}\label{SK141}
0<p_k\leq p^+<1/2,~-p^+\leq q_k<0,~0<p_{-k}\leq p^-<1/2,~-p^-\leq q_{-k}<0,
\end{equation}
and these series converge
\begin{equation}\label{SK142}
\sum\limits_{k=1}^{\infty}|p_k^2-q_k^2|=Q^+,\quad \sum\limits_{k=1}^{\infty}|p_{-k}^2-q_{-k}^2|=Q^-.
\end{equation}\begin{lemma}\label{l.lem1}

If conditions (\ref{SK2}), (\ref{SK3}), (\ref{SK141}), (\ref{SK142}) are true,
then the following inequalities are true
$$
|I_+(re^{i\theta})|\leq2p^+\ln(1+\csc(\theta/2))+\frac{Q^++(p^+)^2}{\Delta_+\kappa_+
\ln t_1}, \quad 0<\theta<2\pi,
$$
$$
|I_-(re^{i\theta})|\leq2p^-\ln(1+\csc((\theta-\pi)/2))+\frac{Q^-+(p^-)^2}{\Delta_-\kappa_-
\ln |t_{-1}|},\quad -\pi<\theta<\pi.
$$
\end{lemma}
The idea of proving this is borrowed from P. G. Jurov  \cite{Yu2}. For $\zeta=re^{i\theta}$ we introduce the function $I_+(\zeta)$ as
$$
I_+(\zeta)=\int\limits_{t_1}^{r}\frac{n_+^*(\tau)-\Delta_+\ln^{\kappa_+}\tau}{\tau}d\tau-\int\limits_{t_1}^{r}\frac{n_+^*(\tau)-\Delta_+\ln^{\kappa_+}\tau}{(\tau-\zeta)}d\tau-
$$$$
-\zeta\int\limits_{r}^{+\infty}\frac{n_+^*(\tau)-\Delta_+\ln^{\kappa_+}\tau}{\tau(\tau-\zeta)}d\tau=I_{+,1}(\zeta)+I_{+,2}(\zeta)+I_{+,3}(\zeta).
$$
Because of the monotony on the interval $(t_j,t_{j+1}),$$j=\overline{1,\infty},$ of function
$n_+^*(\tau)-\Delta_+\ln^{\kappa_+}\tau$ and condition (\ref{SK141}) we obtain inequality  $|n_+^*(\tau)-\Delta_+\ln^{\kappa_+}\tau|<p^+$.
By making an estimate  under the  integral sign in formula for $I_{+,1}(\zeta)$ modulo, we obtain
$$
|I_{+,3}(re^{i\theta})|\leq p^+\ln\biggl(1+\csc\frac{\theta}{2}\biggr).
$$
Similarly for  $I_{+,2}(re^{i\theta})$ we have
$$
|I_{+,2}(re^{i\theta})|\leq p^+\int\limits_{t_1}^{r}\frac{d\tau}{|\tau-\zeta|}\leq
p^+\int\limits_{0}^{1}\frac{d\tau}{|\tau-e^{i\theta}|}=
p^+\ln\biggl(1+\csc\frac{\theta}{2}\biggr).
$$
To estimate $I_{+,1}(\zeta),$$\zeta=re^{i\theta},$$r\in (t_k,t_{k+1}),$
we consider the integral
$$
J(r)=\int\limits_{t_1}^{r}\frac{(n_+^*(\tau)-\Delta_+\ln^{\kappa_+}\tau)\ln^{\kappa_+-1}\tau}{\tau}d\tau.
$$
Taking into account the equality
$$
\int\limits_{t_j}^{t_{j+1}}\frac{(n_+^*(\tau)-\Delta_+\ln^{\kappa_+}\tau)\ln^{\kappa_+-1}\tau}{\tau}d\tau=\frac{1}{2\Delta_+\kappa_+}(p_j^2-q_j^2)
$$
and condition (\ref{SK141}), we obtain
$
J(r)=\left|\biggr(\sum\limits_{j=1}^{k-1}(p_j^2-q_j^2)+
\bigl(n_+^*(\tau)-\Delta_+\ln^{\kappa_+}\tau\bigl)^2\biggr)\biggl|^{t_k}_{r}\bigl/(2\Delta_+\kappa_+)\right|.
$
With reference to conditions (\ref{SK142}), (\ref{SK141}) we have
$
J(r)\leq\bigl({Q^++(p^+)^2}\bigl)\bigl/{(2\Delta_+\kappa_+)}.
$
Writing the integral $I_{+,1}(\zeta)$ as
$$
I_{+,1}(\zeta)=\int\limits_{t_1}^{r}\frac{1}{\ln^{\kappa_+-1}\tau}\cdot
\frac{(n_+^*(\tau)-\Delta_+\ln^{\kappa_+}\tau)\ln^{\kappa_+-1}\tau}{\tau}d\tau,
$$
in accordance with Lemma  22.2 from \cite{Go}, we obtain the
inequality
$
|I_{+,1}(\zeta)|\leq{(Q^++(p^+)^2)}\bigl/{(\Delta_+\kappa_+\ln^{\kappa_+}t_1)}
$
for any sufficiently large number $r=|\zeta|$.
Thus, we have
$$
|I_{+}(\zeta)|\leq2p^+\ln\biggl(1+\csc\frac{\theta}{2}\biggr)+
\frac{(Q^++(p^+)^2)}{\Delta_+\kappa_+\ln^{\kappa_+}t_1}.
$$
Similarly, we obtain the estimate for $I_{-}(\zeta)$. Lemma \ref{l.lem1} is proved.


Next, we need a formula of P. G.  Jurov  (see theorem 1, work \cite{Yu1}):
$$
\frac{\zeta}{2\pi}\int\limits_R^{+\infty}\frac{\ln^\alpha \tau}{\tau(\tau-\zeta)}d\tau=
-\frac{i(2\pi i)^\alpha}{\alpha+1}B_{\alpha+1}\biggl(\frac{\ln\zeta}{2\pi i}\biggr)-
\frac{(2\pi i)^\alpha}{\alpha+1}\cdot\frac{\zeta}{2\pi}\int\limits_R^{+\infty}
\frac{\varphi_{\alpha}(\tau)}{\tau(\tau-\zeta)}d\tau +P_\alpha(\zeta),
$$
where $R\geq1,$$\alpha>0,$$B_{\alpha+1}(w)$ is Bernoulli polynomial:
$$
B_{\alpha+1}(w)=\sum\limits_{k=0}^{[\alpha]+2}C_{\alpha+1}^kB_kw^{\alpha+1-k},
$$$C_{\alpha+1}^k$ are binomial coefficients, $B_k$ are Bernoulli numbers: $B_0=1$,
$B_1=-1/2,$$B_2=1/6,$$B_3=0,$$B_4=-1/30$ etc.
Single-valued branches of functions $\ln z,$$\ln^{\alpha}z$ are to be
chosen so,  that the inequalities  $\ln\tau>0,$$\ln^\alpha\tau>0$ are performed on the upper side of the cutting, done on the real axis from point
$\tau=1$ to the point at infinity. $P_\alpha(z)$ is a holomorphic function for $|\zeta|>R$,
$$
\varphi_\alpha(\tau):=\sum\limits_{m=[\alpha]+2+k_0}^\infty\left(\sum\limits_{n=0}^{[\alpha]+2}
C_{\alpha+1}^nB_nC_{\alpha+1-n}^{m-n}\right)\biggl(\frac{2\pi i}{\ln\tau}\biggr)^{m-\alpha
-1},
$$
and $k_0=3,$ if $[\alpha]$ is even, and $k_0=2,$ if $[\alpha]$ is uneven.

Taking into account the formula of P. G. Jurov we rewrite (\ref{SK12}), (\ref{SK13})
\begin{equation}\label{SK14}
\ln P_+(\zeta)=\frac{\Delta_+}{1+\kappa_+}\ln^{\kappa_++1}\zeta-i\pi\Delta_+
\ln^{\kappa_+}\zeta-\frac{\kappa_+\pi^2\Delta_+}{3}\ln^{\kappa_+-1}\zeta+I_+(\zeta)+O(1),
\end{equation}\begin{equation}\label{SK15}
\ln P_-(\zeta)=\frac{\Delta_-}{1+\kappa_-}\ln^{1+\kappa_-}(-\zeta)-i\pi\Delta_-
\ln^{\kappa_-}(-\zeta)
-\frac{\kappa_-\pi^2\Delta_-}{3}\ln^{\kappa_--1}(-\zeta)+I_-(\zeta)+O(1).
\end{equation}
For $\zeta=re^{i\theta},$$\theta\in(0,\pi),$$r\to+\infty,$ we obtain
$$
\ln P_+(\zeta)=\frac{\Delta_+}{1+\kappa_+}\ln^{\kappa_++1}r+2\kappa_+\pi^2\Delta_+\biggl(-
\frac{\theta^2}{4\pi^2}+\frac{\theta}{2\pi}-\frac{1}{6}\biggr)\ln^{\kappa_+-1}r
-i\pi\Delta_+\biggl(1-\frac{\theta}{\pi}\biggr)\ln^{\kappa_+}r-
$$$$
-i\pi^3\Delta_+\kappa_+(\kappa_+-1)\biggl(\frac{\theta^3}{6\pi^3}+\frac{\theta}{3\pi}-
\frac{\theta^2}{2\pi^2}\biggr)\ln^{\kappa_+-2}r+I_+(\zeta)+O(1),
$$
and, granting $re^{i(\theta+\pi)}=-\zeta,$ we obtain
$$
\ln P_-(\zeta)=\frac{\Delta_-}{1+\kappa_-}\ln^{1+\kappa_-}r+2\kappa_-\pi^2\Delta_-\biggl(
\frac{1}{12}-\frac{\theta^2}{4\pi^2}\biggr)\ln^{\kappa_--1}r+i\pi\Delta_-\theta
\ln^{\kappa_-}r-
$$$$-i\pi^3\kappa_-(\kappa_--1)\Delta_-\biggl(\frac{\theta^3}{6\pi^3}-
\frac{\theta}{6\pi}\biggr)\ln^{\kappa_--2}r+I_-(\zeta)+O(1).
$$
Now the formula (\ref{SK9}) can be represented as
\begin{equation}\label{SK151}
z'(re^{i\theta})=a_0\frac{e^{i\eta_0^1\pi}e^{I_-(re^{i\theta})-I_+(re^{i\theta})}}{r^{1-(\eta_0^2-\eta_0^1)}e^{i\theta(1-(\eta_0^2-\eta_0^1))}}
\exp\biggl(\frac{\Delta_-(\ln r)^{1+\kappa_-}}{1+\kappa_-}
\biggl.-\frac{\Delta_+(\ln r)^{1+\kappa_+}}{1+\kappa_+}+o((\ln r)^{1+\kappa_-})+
o((\ln r)^{1+\kappa_+})\biggr).
\end{equation}
Inserting the latter expression in (\ref{SK11}) and estimating modulo we obtain the
inequality
$
|z(-r)-z(r)|\leq a_{0}{l_{-}r^{(\eta_0^2-\eta_0^1)} /{l_{+}}}
\int\limits_{0}^\pi \exp\{\Re[ I_-(re^{i\theta})-I_+(re^{i\theta})]\}d\theta,$ where $l_{\pm}= \exp\bigl\{\frac{\Delta_\pm}{1+\kappa_\pm}\ln^{1+\kappa_\pm}r+o(\ln^{1+\kappa_\pm}r).$
Taking into account the inequalities of Lemma \ref{l.lem1} we have
$$
\int\limits_0^\pi e^{\Re[ I_-(re^{i\theta})-I_+(re^{i\theta})]}d\theta<\tilde{C}
\int\limits_0^\pi\biggl(1+\csc\frac{\theta}{2}\biggr)^{2p^+}\biggl
(1+\csc\frac{\theta+\pi}{2}\biggr)^{2p^-}d\theta<+\infty.
$$
It is clear that if
$
\kappa_-<\kappa_+$, or
$\kappa_-=\kappa_+$, and  $\Delta_-<\Delta_+$,
then $\lim\limits_{r\to+\infty}|z(-r)-z(r)|=0,$ both limits $\lim\limits_{r\to+\infty}z(r)$ and $\lim\limits_{r\to-\infty}z(r)$ exist and are equal, hence, domain $D_z$ is finite. If
$
\kappa_->\kappa_+$,  or
$\kappa_-=\kappa_+$, and $\Delta_->\Delta_+,
$
then, according to (\ref{SK10}) and (\ref{SK151}) we have
$\lim\limits_{r\to+\infty}z(r)=\lim\limits_{r\to-\infty}z(r)=\infty$ and, consequently,
lines $L_z^1$ and $L_z^2$ are connected at the point at infinity.



Let's consider the question of univalence of  mappings by function (\ref{SK10}), wherein  the numbers $\eta_0^1$, $\eta_0^2$ are defined, sequences of points $t_k,$$t_{-k}$ and numbers $\kappa_k$, $\kappa_{-k}$ satisfy conditions (\ref{SK2}),
(\ref{SK3}). We assume, that there are $\kappa_+=\kappa_-=1,$$\Delta_+=\Delta_-=\Delta$ in condition (\ref{SK2}).
Here we need the following condition for the univalence of analytic functions in the half-plane.
\begin{lemma}\label{l.lem2}
If the analytical in the upper half-plane $D$ function $z(\zeta)$ satisfies the inequality
\begin{equation}\label{SK16}
2\eta\biggl|\frac{z''(\zeta)}{z'(\zeta)}+\frac{1-\beta
}{\zeta}\biggr|<\beta\tan(\beta\pi/4),\quad\zeta=\xi+i\eta,
\end{equation}
for some $\beta,$ $0<\beta\leq1,$ then $z(\zeta)$ is univalent at  $D.$
\end{lemma}{\bf Proof.} From theorem 1 of \cite{ASh}(see also \cite{ASh1}, theorem 12) follow that if the analytical, inside the angular domain $D_\beta$ with angle $\beta\pi$, function $f(w)$
 satisfies the inequality in every point of $w\in D_\beta$\begin{equation}\label{SK17}
\rho^{-1}_{D_\beta}(w)\biggl|\frac{f''(w)}{f'(w)}\biggr|<\beta\tan(\beta\pi/4),
\end{equation}
where $\rho_{D_\beta}(w)$ is the density of the hyperbolic metric of domain $D_\beta$ at point $w$, see \cite{Go}(ch. 8), \cite{Awh2}(ch. 3), then $f(w)$ is univalent at  $D_\beta$. If conformal mapping of the domain $D_\beta$ to half-plane $D$ is denoted by the symbol $\zeta(w)$, then
$$
\rho_{D_\beta}(w):=\frac{|\zeta'(w)|}{2\Im\zeta(w)}\Longrightarrow |w'(\zeta)|=\frac{1}{\rho_{D_\beta}(w)2\Im\zeta},\quad w=w(\zeta).
$$
Let $w(\zeta)$, inverse to function $\zeta(w)$, map $D$ onto
angular domain $D_\beta$. We introduce analytical in $D_\beta$ function $f(w)=z\circ\zeta(w)$ and consider the complicated function, defined in the half-plane $z(\zeta)=f\circ w(\zeta).$ Then find $\ln z'(\zeta)-\ln w'(\zeta)=\ln f'(w).$  On both sides of the latter equation we take the derivative with respect to $\zeta.$ We obtain
$$
\frac{z''(\zeta)}{z'(\zeta)}-\frac{w''(\zeta)}{w'(\zeta)}=\frac{f''(w)}{f'(w)}w'(\zeta).
$$
Since we can take $w(\zeta)=\zeta^\beta,$ the latter equation takes the form of
$$
\frac{z''(\zeta)}{z'(\zeta)}+(1-\beta)\frac{1}{\zeta}=\frac{f''(w)}{f'(w)}w'(\zeta).
$$
Taking the module from both sides of the equation and replacing $|w'(\zeta)|$ with
$(\rho_{D_\beta}(w)2\Im\zeta(w))^{-1},$ we obtain
$$
\biggl|\frac{z''(\zeta)}{z'(\zeta)}+(1-\beta)\frac{1}{\zeta}\biggr|=
\biggl|\frac{f''(w)}{f'(w)}\biggr|\rho^{-1}_{D_\beta}(w)\frac{1}{2\Im\zeta}.
$$
So here it is
\begin{equation}\label{SK18}
2\eta\biggl|\frac{z''(\zeta)}{z'(\zeta)}+(1-\beta)\frac{1}{\zeta}\biggr|
=\biggl|\frac{f''(w)}{f'(w)}\biggr|\rho^{-1}_{D_\beta}(w),\quad w=w(\zeta).
\end{equation}
If $z(\zeta)$ satisfies condition (\ref{SK16}), then taking into account equality (\ref{SK18}),
function $f(w)$ satisfies inequality (\ref{SK17}), hence, $f(w)$ is univalent in $D_\beta$, and so  $z(\zeta)$ is univalent in $D$. Lemma \ref{l.lem2} is proved. F.G. Avhadiev developed the theory of admissible functionals (see \cite{Avh}). Similar conditions of univalence can also be obtained from this theory.

Applying Lemma \ref{l.lem2}  we need the following estimates.
From formula (\ref{SK10}) we obtain
\begin{equation}\label{SK19}
\frac{z''(\zeta)}{z'(\zeta)}+\frac{1- (\eta_0^2-\eta_0^1)}{\zeta}=
(\ln P_-(\zeta)-\ln P_+(\zeta))'.
\end{equation}
Let's denote $D_\rho^+=\{\zeta:|\zeta|<\rho\},$ where $\rho$ is a positive big number. Let $\rho>R,$$D_\rho^-={\mathbb C}\setminus\overline{D_\rho^+}$. For $\zeta\in D_\rho^-$ from formulas
 (\ref{SK14}), (\ref{SK15}), when $\kappa_+=\kappa_-=1,$$\Delta_+=\Delta_-=\Delta $ we deduce
$$
\ln P_-(\zeta)-\ln P_+(\zeta)=\frac{\Delta}{2}(\ln^2(-\zeta)-\ln^2(\zeta))-i\pi\Delta
(\ln(-\zeta)-\ln(\zeta))+
+P_1(-\zeta)-P_1(\zeta)+I_-(\zeta)-I_+(\zeta),
$$
from $\ln(-\zeta)=\ln(\zeta)+i\pi,$ we obtain
$
\ln P_-(\zeta)-\ln P_+(\zeta)=i\Delta\pi\ln\zeta+\pi^2\Delta+I_-(\zeta)-
I_+(\zeta)+P_1(-\zeta)-P_1(\zeta).
$
Hence, we find
\begin{equation}\label{SK20}
(\ln P_-(\zeta)-\ln P_+(\zeta))'=\frac{i\Delta\pi}{\zeta}+I'_-(\zeta)-I_+'(\zeta)+
P'_1(-\zeta)-P'_1(\zeta).
\end{equation}
Differentiating under the integral sign in the second formula from (\ref{SK12}), we obtain
$$
I'_+(\zeta)=
-\int\limits_{t_1}^{+\infty}\frac{n^*_+(\tau)-\Delta\ln\tau}{(\tau-\zeta)^2}d\tau.
$$
Using condition (\ref{SK141}) when $\zeta=\xi+i\eta$ we write the estimate
\begin{equation}\label{SK22}
|I'_+(\zeta)|\leq\int\limits_{t_1}^{+\infty}\frac{|n^*_+(\tau)-\Delta\ln\tau|}{(\tau-\xi)^2+\eta^2}d\tau<\frac{\pi p_+}{2\eta},~\zeta\in D.
\end{equation}
Let's take into account that function $P_1(\zeta)$ is holomorphic in the neighborhood of the 	 point at infinity, hence, the expansion has the form of
$$
P_1(\zeta)=b+\frac{b_{-1}}{\zeta}+\frac{b_{-2}}{\zeta^2}+\cdots,\quad\zeta\in\overline{D_\rho^-},
$$
hence,
$$
P'_1(\zeta)=-\frac{b_{-1}}{\zeta^2}-\frac{2b_{-2}}{\zeta^3}-\cdots,\quad \zeta\in\overline{D_\rho^-}.
$$
We choose the number $\rho$ such, so that on circuit  $\partial D_\rho^-$ we have the inequality $|P'_1(\zeta)|<1$. From Lemma of Schwarz (\cite{Go}, p. 29) for function
$g(\omega)=P'_1(1/\omega),$$\zeta=1/\omega,$ which is regular in circle $|\omega|<\rho^{-1},$
and vanishes in origin and is bounded modulo by one  $|g(\omega)|<\rho|\omega|,$ i.e. for $\zeta\in D_\rho^-$ equation  $|P'_1(\zeta)|<\rho/|\zeta|$ is true
and, hence, for $\zeta=\xi+i\eta,$$
|P'_1(\zeta)|<{\rho}/{\eta},\quad \zeta\in \overline{D_\rho^-}
$
is right. Estimating modulo the left part in equation (\ref{SK20}), using the latter relation,
inequality (24), analogous inequality for $|I'_-(\zeta)|$, we obtain
\begin{equation}\label{SK25}
|(\ln P_-(\zeta)-\ln P_+(\zeta))'|\leq\frac{(2\Delta+p^++p^-)\pi+4\rho}{2\eta},~
\zeta=\xi+i\eta\in D\cap\overline{D_\rho^-}.
\end{equation}
For $D\cap D_\rho^+$ from formulas (\ref{SK12}), (\ref{SK13}) let's write
\begin{equation}\label{SK26}
(\ln P_-(\zeta)-\ln P_+(\zeta))'=\left(\zeta\Delta\int\limits_{t_1}^{+\infty}\frac{\ln\tau d\tau}{\tau(\tau-\zeta)}\right)'+\left(\zeta\Delta\int\limits_{-t_{-1}}^{+\infty}\frac{\ln\tau d\tau}{\tau(\tau+\zeta)}\right)'+I'_-(\zeta)-I_+'(\zeta).
\end{equation}
Writing the integral as
$$
\zeta\int\limits_{t_1}^{+\infty}\frac{\ln\tau d\tau}{\tau(\tau-\zeta)}=
\int\limits_{t_1}^{2\rho}\frac{\ln\tau d\tau}{(\tau-\zeta)}-
\int\limits_{t_1}^{2\rho}\frac{\ln\tau d\tau}{\tau}+\zeta\int\limits_{2\rho}^{+\infty}\frac{\ln\tau d\tau}{\tau(\tau-\zeta)}=\Phi_1(\zeta)+\Phi_1(0)+\Phi_2(\zeta),
$$
we estimate the derivatives of summands. The next inequality is obvious
$$
|\Phi'_2(\zeta)|<\int\limits_{2\rho}^{+\infty}\frac{\ln\tau d\tau}{4\tau^2}<\frac{1+\ln(2\rho)}{8\rho},~\zeta\in D_\rho^+.
$$
From \cite{Ga} Cauchy-type integral for the open loop is represented as
$$
\Phi_1(\zeta)=-\ln t\ln(\zeta-t_1)+\ln t\ln(\zeta-2\rho)+\int\limits_{t_1}^{2\rho}
\frac{(\ln\tau-\ln t)d\tau}{(\tau-\zeta)}, ~ t_1\leq t\leq\rho.
$$
In point $\zeta=\xi+i\eta,$$0<\xi<\rho,$ we calculate the derivative
$$
\Phi'_1(\zeta)=-\frac{\ln t}{\zeta-t_1}+\frac{\ln t}{\zeta-2\rho}+\int\limits_{t_1}^{2\rho}
\frac{(\ln\tau-\ln t)d\tau}{(\tau-\zeta)^2},
$$
its evaluation for $t=\xi$, taking into account the Lipschitz condition for the density of the Cauchy integral, results in the inequality
$$|\Phi'_1(\zeta)|\leq\frac{\ln\rho}{\eta}+\frac{2}{t_1}(-\ln\eta+\ln(\rho\sqrt[4]{10}))<
\frac{\ln\rho+2\rho\sqrt[4]{10}}{\eta},
~\zeta\in D\cap{D_\rho^+}.
$$
Thus, we evaluate (\ref{SK26}) and obtain
\begin{equation}\label{SK27}
|(\ln P_-(\zeta)-\ln P_+(\zeta))'|\leq\frac{4\Delta(\ln \rho+2\rho\sqrt[4]{10})+(p^++p^-)\pi}{2\eta},~
\zeta=\xi+i\eta\in D\cap{D_\rho^+}.
\end{equation}
The existence of constant $C$  follows from evaluations (\ref{SK25}), (\ref{SK27}), so that the inequality
\begin{equation}\label{SK28}
|(\ln P_-(\zeta)-\ln P_+(\zeta))'|\leq\frac{C}{\eta}
\end{equation}
is true for all $\zeta=\xi+i\eta\in D$.

Now we consider the same sequence of points of real axis $t_k$, $t_{-k}$,
satisfying condition (\ref{SK2}), let's denote a small positive number as $\lambda$ and
consider the sequence of numbers $\lambda\kappa_k,$$\lambda\kappa_{-k},$ then we construct a function with reference to (\ref{SK10})
\begin{equation}\label{SK29}
z_\lambda(\zeta)=a_0\int\limits_0^\zeta\frac{e^{i\eta_0^1\pi}P_{-,\lambda}(\zeta)}{\zeta^{1-(\eta_0^2-\eta_0^1)}P_{+,\lambda}(\zeta)} d\zeta.
\end{equation}
Thus, we have
$$
n_-^\lambda(\xi)=\left\lbrace\begin{array}{ll} \displaystyle{0,\quad
0<\xi<-t_{-1},}\\[3mm] \displaystyle{\sum\limits_{j=1}^k\lambda\kappa_{-j},~
-t_{-k}<\xi<-t_{-k-1}},
\end{array}\right.
\quad n_+^\lambda(\xi)=\left\lbrace\begin{array}{ll} \displaystyle{0,\quad
0<\xi<t_1,}\\[3mm] \displaystyle{\sum\limits_{j=1}^k\lambda\kappa_{j},~
t_k<\xi<t_{k+1}},
\end{array}\right.
$$
hence, $ n_-^\lambda(\xi)=\lambda n_-^*(\xi),$$ n_+^\lambda(\xi)=
\lambda n_+^*(\xi).$ Thus, the sequence of numbers $\lambda\kappa_k,$$\lambda\kappa_{-k},$ satisfies conditions (\ref{SK2}) with constants
$\lambda\Delta_+,$$\lambda\Delta_-$.

The function (\ref{SK29}) will map the upper half-plane onto a polygonal region with given angles $\tilde\alpha_k\pi,$$\tilde\alpha_{-k}\pi,$$k=\overline{1,\infty},$$\tilde\alpha_k=1-\lambda\kappa_k,$$\tilde\alpha_{-k}=\lambda\kappa_{-k}+1,$
at unknown vertices $A_k,$$A_{-k}$. Thus we have
$$
P_{+,\lambda}(\zeta)=\prod\limits_{k=1}^{\infty}\left(1-\frac{\zeta}{t_{k}}\right)
^{\lambda\kappa_{k}},\quad
P_{-,\lambda}(\zeta)=\prod\limits_{k=1}^{\infty}\left(1-\frac{\zeta}{t_{-k}}\right)
^{\lambda\kappa_{-k}},
$$
therefore, $\ln P_{-,\lambda}(\zeta)-\ln P_{+,\lambda}(\zeta)=
\lambda[\ln P_-(\zeta)-\ln P_+(\zeta)],$ and from (\ref{SK28}) we have
\begin{equation}\label{SK30}
|(\ln P_{-,\lambda}(\zeta)-\ln P_{+,\lambda}(\zeta))'|
\leq\frac{\lambda C}{\eta}.
\end{equation}
From formulas (\ref{SK29}), (\ref{SK22}) we obtain
$$
\frac{z''_\lambda(\zeta)}{z'_\lambda(\zeta)}+\frac{1- (\eta_0^2-\eta_0^1)}{\zeta}=
(\ln P_{-,\lambda}(\zeta))'-(\ln P_{+,\lambda}(\zeta))'.
$$
Assuming now $\beta=\eta_0^2-\eta_0^1$ and taking into account (\ref{SK30}) we conclude,
that for sufficiently small $\lambda$ function (\ref{SK29}) will satisfy the sufficient condition for the univalence (\ref{SK16}).

Therefore, we have the following assertion.

\begin{theorem}\label{}
If any two sequences of points $t_{-k}$, $t_k$ are satisfy the condition
(\ref{SK3}) and limits (\ref{SK2})  with $\kappa_+=\kappa_-=1$  are equal for this sequences, else there are infinitely many sequences of numbers $\alpha_{-k},$ and $\alpha_k$,
 $k=\overline{1,\infty}$, for which the mapping (\ref{SK10}) is univalent.
\end{theorem}
